commit_message:
Support to run cluster test using existing cluster template

- This fix is primarily focused on using existing cluster template
  use case.
- Rename 'keypair_id' to 'keypair_name' in the magnum tempest config.
- Add 'cluster_template_id' and 'cluster_creation_timeout' config
  options.
- Move the cluster template and keypair to the class-scoped resources.

Change-Id: Ib5260757e373ce545ca6900acf8871b6d96dcfb8

[{'created': '2019-04-09 19:51:37.000000000', 'message': 'turn off docker registry mirror if using local libvirt

The direct connection to docker.io is more
reliable when running directly from libvirt.

When using the reproducer, a mirror is defined
and the docker registry mirror will be set and used.
This often fails, so use docker.io instead.

Change-Id: Id6ae9bbab5b92c64dfa544bcb55299f57b67c60d
'}]
commit_message:
turn off docker registry mirror if using local libvirt

The direct connection to docker.io is more
reliable when running directly from libvirt.

When using the reproducer, a mirror is defined
and the docker registry mirror will be set and used.
This often fails, so use docker.io instead.

Change-Id: Id6ae9bbab5b92c64dfa544bcb55299f57b67c60d

diff from merged stein to PS2:

 62,63c62,68
 < with an old flavor (gen1) to a new flavor (gen2) in a new cell. This eases up
 < admins/operators to drain old cells with old hardware.
 ---
 > with an old flavor (gen1) to a new flavor (gen2) in a new cell.
 > 
 > Users, by naturally resizing their servers every once in a while, will help
 > with the migration. If not, the admins can also give them "new" flavors and
 > tell them they need to resize their servers by a certain date. By having this
 > be doable by a user-controlled process, the users can help with the migration
 > without knowing anything about cells underneath.
 87c92,93
 < * There is no SSH access between compute hosts in different cells.
 ---
 > * There is a lack of connectivity, e.g. SSH access, between compute hosts in
 >   different cells on which regular resize relies.
 322c328
 < * RPC call to the source compute to destroy the guest (including disks)
 ---
 > * RPC call to the source compute to cleanup disks
 359a366,368
 > * Mark the source cell DB instance as ``hidden=False`` to show it from the API
 >   while listing servers as we revert.
 > 
 421a431,448
 > 3. Servers created with personality files, commonly known as file injection,
 >    that are resized across cells will lose the personality files since they are
 >    not persisted in the database. There are two ways to view this. First is
 >    that a traditional resize will preserve a config drive with the personality
 >    files in it, so this would be a regression from that behavior since the
 >    config drive is going to get rebuilt on the destination host during a cross
 >    cell resize. On the other hand, servers with personality files that are
 >    resized today but do not have a config drive already lose their personality
 >    files during the migration because the files are not persisted and therefore
 >    even if they get metadata in the guest from the metadata API, they will not
 >    get the personality files used during server create (or the last rebuild).
 >    Similarly, servers that are evacuated, even if they had a config drive, will
 >    lose the personality files during the evacuation since the config drive is
 >    rebuilt on the destination host. It is also worth noting that the use of

commit_message:
Re-propose cross-cell-resize spec for Train

There are a few clarifications added based on the stein
spec review feedback: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/616037/

A known issue is added for personality files not being retained
in the config drive during a cross-cell resize.

A link to the code series is added in the References section
and the History section is updated for Train.

Details about the need to hard-delete the instance and its
related records is also added since the Stein spec.

Previously-approved: Stein

Spec for blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: I68498afd481f7291a6102928d7999b4be49ded7a

commit_message:
Make ovn package python version aware

After merging [1] fedora28 container build is failing [2], the issue is
that fedora28 package name is python3-networking-ovn, this review uses
this name for python3 distros.

Closes-Bug: #1824141

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/644587/
[2] http://logs.rdoproject.org/openstack-periodic/git.openstack.org/openstack-infra/tripleo-ci/master/periodic-tripleo-fedora-28-master-containers-build-push/bab384a/logs/build.log.txt.gz

Change-Id: Ic01d8232cb9385c415fb46cdd401e4dff301e6ee

'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-01-16 02:56:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-01-16 09:20:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-01-16 09:22:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-01-16 20:58:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-01-16 21:04:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-01-16 21:04:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-01-16 21:08:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-01-16 21:21:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 20207, 'date': '2019-01-16 21:52:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@Chris, you have been an active contributor for previous version of this blueprint. This new one covers more details and been updated with integration in to Nova. Could you please review?'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-01-17 21:58:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2019-01-18 16:58:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-2

(8 comments)

This would be taking us back 3+ years. I'm a hard -2 on it.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-01-18 20:03:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(6 comments)

Hi Jay Pipes,

I have attempted to clarify some of your comments. Kindly revisit them.

RMD is a local node daemon independent of Openstack to primarily provide short-term dynamic fine-tuning of resources. We are suggesting the means to Openstack to utilize RMD and would like the control for tracking/allocation to come from Openstack. 

Please recommend any changes to meet this goal in Openstack.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-01-18 23:26:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(19 comments)

I agree with Jay that, as written, this violates a number of architectural principles that we've been sweating to build up in nova/placement over the past several years. However, I think there's still the potential to introduce at least some of the capabilities of RMD within that framework.

I recommend starting small. For example:

=============
Introduce a new standard resource class, e.g. MIN_L3_CACHE_MB, to be statically allocated to a VM like any other resource.

The virt driver, within update_provider_tree, queries RMD. If there is no RMD, no-op. If RMD is there, it responds with the amount of available L3 cache, which the driver puts into the inventory for the compute node resource provider. (Don't try to do NUMA splits at this point, since we don't have the processors properly represented that way yet.)

The operator can request the resource in the flavor in the usual way, e.g.:

 resource:MIN_L3_CACHE_MB=4096

Nova takes care of scheduling and allocation via placement without needing any changes.

The virt driver, within the spawn method, looks at the allocation, notices it contains some MIN_L3_CACHE_MB, and sends that information to RMD, which assigns that guaranteed minimum quantity to the VM.

In other words, you're quite simply introducing a new resource class, which is available if the admin has gone through the necessary steps to configure RMD on a given node.

I recognize that this leaves out dynamic reconfiguration/reallocation. I'm afraid this is a non-starter if we're talking about real resources. However, I wouldn't think there's anything stopping RMD from treating any unallocated L3 cache as a shared pool and shunting it around among VMs on demand, as long as everybody has their guaranteed minimums. In other words, if RMD wants to perform optimizations under the covers, that's none of Nova's business - as long as allocated resources stay allocated.

Another point: I didn't fully grok all the options available for communicating with RMD from nova, but it would be nice if it weren't a new service with a REST API. It sounded like there might be a "special file system" mechanism? That would represent a much smaller footprint to the ecosystem and be far preferable IMO.
=============

@Jay, can you see supporting an effort framed more like the above?'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-01-23 04:38:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Some notes from me:

* I suggest this proposal is focusing on L3 cache allocation than a generic resource management daemon management. Only for l3 cache resource allocation and structure is very complex I don't think we can proposal a generic framework to handle all the resources, and there is no clear definition of what kind of resources RMD will manage in the future, it is just a vision.

* CAT is about allocating specific number of cache line to specific process on specific physical cpu core. That mean it is only meaning for cpu pinning instance. And l3 cache is per socket. So I want to see more detail how to deal with cpu pinning and how to struct the resource with numa topology and socket.

* CAT also have the fragmental issue. The cache lines are allocated to a process on a pcpu core must be continues. so I hope we have detial about this. Like the idea I said fixed size.

* min_cache/max_cache model. @Eric, yes, I also think about that. This is back to first denver PTG probably, I talk with jay, Placement is only guaranteed the minumal resource requirement. The RMD take care of the max_cache, the RMD is responsible for shrink or grow the cache allcoation for a VM. But after talk with Dakshina, the RMD have different model, the RMD won't shrink the cache allocation for any new VM request, which I don't understand. And the model of RMD report back the allocation to the placement when grow the allocation, which as most people know won't works, since there is race problem. I hope Dakshina input something this in the spec and get discussion with more wide."}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-01-23 06:44:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-01-23 06:52:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-01-23 07:18:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> Some notes from me:
 > 
 > * I suggest this proposal is focusing on L3 cache allocation than a
 > generic resource management daemon management. Only for l3 cache
 > resource allocation and structure is very complex I don't think we
 > can proposal a generic framework to handle all the resources, and
 > there is no clear definition of what kind of resources RMD will
 > manage in the future, it is just a vision.
 > 
RMD aims to control resources that require local monitoring and faster reaction time to do any changes for performance. The document intends to show LLC as an example. We would like to identify an approach for Openstack to leverage resources in the umbrella of RMD. Ideally we want to identify a uniform approach to include a new resource into placement, flavor requests and how requests can be delegated to RMD/inventory information be obtained from RMD for placement.

 > * CAT is about allocating specific number of cache line to specific
 > process on specific physical cpu core. That mean it is only meaning
 > for cpu pinning instance. And l3 cache is per socket. So I want to
 > see more detail how to deal with cpu pinning and how to struct the
 > resource with numa topology and socket.
 > 
Partially true. We do not require CPU pinning information if cache lines are dedicated to a specific process. Cache lines can be dedicated to a specific process or specific cores.

Since L3 cache is a resource per socket, we would like to report all the available L3 cache. So we have suggested nested resource providers. 

Secondly, a process may be running on cores from socket 0 but using L3 cache from socket 1. If user wants to co-locate both his cores and L3 cache, we suggested if he can use granular resource requests to request the same.

Please help suggest what additional details may be required for both these details that are specific to LLC.

 > * CAT also have the fragmental issue. The cache lines are allocated
 > to a process on a pcpu core must be continues. so I hope we have
 > detial about this. Like the idea I said fixed size.
 > 

Yes this is unavoidable today and actual available reported by placement need not be available due to fragmentation, unless RMD can come up with a mechanism to defragment cache lines. Defragmentation should not affect the Openstack design.

 > * min_cache/max_cache model. @Eric, yes, I also think about that.
 > This is back to first denver PTG probably, I talk with jay,
 > Placement is only guaranteed the minumal resource requirement. The
 > RMD take care of the max_cache, the RMD is responsible for shrink
 > or grow the cache allcoation for a VM. But after talk with
 > Dakshina, the RMD have different model, the RMD won't shrink the
 > cache allocation for any new VM request, which I don't understand.
 > And the model of RMD report back the allocation to the placement
 > when grow the allocation, which as most people know won't works,
 > since there is race problem. I hope Dakshina input something this
 > in the spec and get discussion with more wide.

@Eric and Alex, we will have a race condition if RMD tries to pass updates on dynamic changes to Placement via Nova compute. 
RMD tries to work with current state - VM scheduled for a min requirement. It later tries to allocate cache for a new VM based on the current state and does not shrink cache for a new VM request since the state has been determined based on performance. 
We shall bring something to the table for this.

Meanwhile, we should close the gaps for static resource allocation and tracking flow (minus special cases like numa topology, fragmentation of LLC or dynamic resource allocation)"}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-04-10 11:07:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

so  in general  its much harder to have converstaion in the top level comment then in the spec so we shyould avoid it

 > RMD aims to control resources that require local monitoring and
 > faster reaction time to do any changes for performance. The
 > document intends to show LLC as an example. We would like to
 > identify an approach for Openstack to leverage resources in the
 > umbrella of RMD. Ideally we want to identify a uniform approach to

so last level cache is not something that required RMD to manage.
it can be done statically via libvirt without RMD

 > 
 > > * CAT is about allocating specific number of cache line to
 > specific
 > > process on specific physical cpu core. That mean it is only
 > meaning
 > > for cpu pinning instance. And l3 cache is per socket. So I want
 > to
 > > see more detail how to deal with cpu pinning and how to struct
 > the
 > > resource with numa topology and socket.
 > >
 > Partially true. We do not require CPU pinning information if cache
 > lines are dedicated to a specific process. Cache lines can be
 > dedicated to a specific process or specific cores.
 > 
 > Since L3 cache is a resource per socket, we would like to report
 > all the available L3 cache. So we have suggested nested resource
 > providers.
l3 cache is not managed per socket there is a cache region per numa node
so unless you have at least an numa toplogy for the guest we could have sever
perfromance hits if we are froced to cross the internal numa boundary in a singel socket.

when you enable cluster on die these internal numa and cache regions get reported
as seperate numa/cache regions to the kernel. we need to model cache as a child RP of a numa node
or even on purly with the mech architeture there will be numa issues.

turning cluster on die off hides the numa toplogy that is internal to the socket
form the kerenl but it also reduces your perfromacne by halving your effective 
memoy bandwith  and leads to less deterministic behavior so it should be on by default.


 > 
 > Secondly, a process may be running on cores from socket 0 but using
 > L3 cache from socket 1. If user wants to co-locate both his cores
 > and L3 cache, we suggested if he can use granular resource requests
 > to request the same.
again this needs to be done at the numa node level not the socket level.
we might be able to use the process id of the primary qemu process to make
this work for floating instance but CAT does not actully allocate
cache to a process it restict the cache ways that it can use.
since caches have numa affintiy i think we shoudl be tracking them at the numa
node level and require that instnace with l3 cache request must have at least
a numa toplogy and preferable be pinned.
 > 
 > Please help suggest what additional details may be required for
 > both these details that are specific to LLC.
 > 
 > > * CAT also have the fragmental issue. The cache lines are
 > allocated
 > > to a process on a pcpu core must be continues. so I hope we have

 > >
 > 
 > Yes this is unavoidable today and actual available reported by
 > placement need not be available due to fragmentation, unless RMD
 > can come up with a mechanism to defragment cache lines.
 > Defragmentation should not affect the Openstack design.

well whether RMD is allowed to deframent is a policy that need to be specifed
by openstack. defragmentation of cache invoes evicting existing cache entries
optionally memcopying the data and that resulted in l3 cache misses for the runnign
applciation.

that woudl not be accpeatble for realtime workloads a hit dram due to rmd defragmenting l3 cache
would likely violate realtime slas.'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-04-10 18:19:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

so last level cache is not something that required RMD to manage.
it can be done statically via libvirt without RMD
[Dakshina] LLC can be directly integrated with Libvirt but the primary reason to do it with RMD
1. Closed loop fine-tuning. After the VM is provisioned (if Libvirt also associates LLC ways to the VM), RMD can fine-tune the LLC allocation values. This is out of scope for this proposal but it is the next step.
2. As first step we introduce LLC from RMD since unlike other resources it requires finer-grain resource control and we introduce addtional QoS from RMD like Guaranteed/Shared e.t.c.


> * CAT is about allocating specific number of cache line to
specific
> process on specific physical cpu core. That mean it is only
meaning
> for cpu pinning instance. And l3 cache is per socket. So I want
to
> see more detail how to deal with cpu pinning and how to struct
the
> resource with numa topology and socket.
>
Partially true. We do not require CPU pinning information if cache
lines are dedicated to a specific process. Cache lines can be
dedicated to a specific process or specific cores.Since L3 cache is a resource per socket, we would like to report
all the available L3 cache. So we have suggested nested resource
providers.
l3 cache is not managed per socket there is a cache region per numa node
so unless you have at least an numa toplogy for the guest we could have sever
perfromance hits if we are froced to cross the internal numa boundary in a singel socket.
when you enable cluster on die these internal numa and cache regions get reported
as seperate numa/cache regions to the kernel. we need to model cache as a child RP of a numa node
or even on purly with the mech architeture there will be numa issues.

turning cluster on die off hides the numa toplogy that is internal to the socket
form the kerenl but it also reduces your perfromacne by halving your effective 
memoy bandwith  and leads to less deterministic behavior so it should be on by default.


 > 
 > Secondly, a process may be running on cores from socket 0 but using
 > L3 cache from socket 1. If user wants to co-locate both his cores
 > and L3 cache, we suggested if he can use granular resource requests
 > to request the same.
again this needs to be done at the numa node level not the socket level.
we might be able to use the process id of the primary qemu process to make
this work for floating instance but CAT does not actully allocate
cache to a process it restict the cache ways that it can use.
since caches have numa affintiy i think we shoudl be tracking them at the numa
node level and require that instnace with l3 cache request must have at least
a numa toplogy and preferable be pinned.

[Dakshina]
Agree to both the comments. This is proposed in the new blueprint.
Please refer - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/651233/

 > 
 > Please help suggest what additional details may be required for
 > both these details that are specific to LLC.
 > 
 > > * CAT also have the fragmental issue. The cache lines are
 > allocated
 > > to a process on a pcpu core must be continues. so I hope we have
 > > detial about this. Like the idea I said fixed size.
 > >
 > 
 > Yes this is unavoidable today and actual available reported by
 > placement need not be available due to fragmentation, unless RMD
 > can come up with a mechanism to defragment cache lines.
 > Defragmentation should not affect the Openstack design.

well whether RMD is allowed to deframent is a policy that need to be specifed
by openstack. defragmentation of cache invoes evicting existing cache entries
optionally memcopying the data and that resulted in l3 cache misses for the runnign
applciation.

that woudl not be accpeatble for realtime workloads a hit dram due to rmd defragmenting l3 cache
would likely violate realtime slas.

[Dakshina] RMD does not defragment today for the same reasons - we could have cache misses and latency from cache warm-up. It can come as a configuration option.'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-04-10 18:22:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

We have changed few design details and introduced new blueprints.

Please refer to the latest and help review there

Resource Management Daemon - Base Enablement
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/651130/

Resource Management Daemon - Last-Level Cache
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/651233/

Resource Management Daemon - CPU P-State
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/651024/'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-04-10 20:39:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> We have changed few design details and introduced new blueprints.

Thanks Dakshina. I'm going to abandon this change set so it doesn't muddy the waters."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-04-10 20:40:04.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

See:

Resource Management Daemon - Base Enablement
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/651130/

Resource Management Daemon - Last-Level Cache
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/651233/

Resource Management Daemon - CPU P-State
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/651024/'}]

commit_message:
Nova changes to support Local Resource Management that uses Resource Management Daemon

We propose a solution for OpenStack Nova to leverage the Resource Management Daemon (RMD) to manage a subset of host resources traditionally not visible to Nova. These are resources that shall allow more fine grain resource control for more predictable performance. This will require running RMD on the compute nodes and modifying Nova Compute.

Implements: blueprint nova-changes-to-support-local-resource-management-that-uses-resource-management-daemon

Change-Id: Idd3a0b678d231e58cb349fdbef6e720194c0e5d9
Signed-off-by: Dakshina Ilangovan <dakshina.ilangovan@intel.com>

use common constants from neutron-lib

This patch switches over to use lib rather than neutron for them as
eventually we'll be removing neutron.common.constants.

commit_message:
Fix get_connector_properties

We get exception oslo_privsep.daemon.FailedToDropPrivileges when calling
cinderlib.get_connector_properties.

This is because we make it point to OS-Brick's original method, which we
later replace when we do the init in nos-brick.  So cinderlib always
call the replaced method, while cinderlib users will be calling the
original OS-Brick method that hasn't replaced the privsep code.

This patch fixes this by assigning our get_connector_properties method
to the cinderlib method during the nos-brick initialization.

We also have a tiny doc change where we were saying connection instead
of connector, and some cosmetic changes in nos_brick to improve
readability, since we were using acronyms bgcp and bcp, which we now
replace for some more meaningful names.

Closes-Bug: #1822976
Change-Id: I627289418d52bdab826d1cf1a941e5671aaf2239

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-02 13:25:10.000000000', 'message': 'Add functional regression test for bug 1669054

Change Ic3968721d257a167f3f946e5387cd227a7eeec6c in Newton
started setting the RequestSpec.ignore_hosts field to the
source instance.host during resize/cold migrate if
allow_resize_to_same_host=False in config, which it is by
default.

Change I8abdf58a6537dd5e15a012ea37a7b48abd726579 also in
Newton persists changes to the RequestSpec in conductor
in order to save the RequestSpec.flavor for the new flavor.
This inadvertently persists the ignore_hosts field as well.

Later if you try to evacuate or unshelve the server it will ignore
the original source host because of the persisted ignore_hosts value.
This is obviously a problem in a small deployment with only a few
compute nodes (like an edge deployment). As a result, an evacuation
can fail if the only available host is the one being ignored.

This adds a functional regression recreate test for the bug.

Change-Id: I6ce2d6b1baf47796f867aede1acf292ec9739d6d
Related-Bug: #1669054
(cherry picked from commit 556cf103b22ab6bebecc9d824d6f918cda38fe3e)
'}]
commit_message:
Add functional regression test for bug 1669054

Change Ic3968721d257a167f3f946e5387cd227a7eeec6c in Newton
started setting the RequestSpec.ignore_hosts field to the
source instance.host during resize/cold migrate if
allow_resize_to_same_host=False in config, which it is by
default.

Change I8abdf58a6537dd5e15a012ea37a7b48abd726579 also in
Newton persists changes to the RequestSpec in conductor
in order to save the RequestSpec.flavor for the new flavor.
This inadvertently persists the ignore_hosts field as well.

Later if you try to evacuate or unshelve the server it will ignore
the original source host because of the persisted ignore_hosts value.
This is obviously a problem in a small deployment with only a few
compute nodes (like an edge deployment). As a result, an evacuation
can fail if the only available host is the one being ignored.

This adds a functional regression recreate test for the bug.

Change-Id: I6ce2d6b1baf47796f867aede1acf292ec9739d6d
Related-Bug: #1669054
(cherry picked from commit 556cf103b22ab6bebecc9d824d6f918cda38fe3e)

commit_message:
Fix a KeyError

Fix a KeyError introduced by the recent change. [1]
The unit tests are taken from the PS1 of the original patch. [2]

Note that super's get_network doesn't fill in provider network
attributes. The ml2 version does it by explicitly calling
self.type_manager.extend_network_dict_provider.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/648522
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/648522/1

Closes-Bug: #1823294
Co-Authored-By: Harald Jensås <hjensas@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I17b4df558cc7fa370a5f930746030cead6a895d9
(cherry picked from commit c760a83a5d9111e48333e1aff5f6dd043cb9e68f)

commit_message:
Allow provider net attr in update if no change

If provider net attributes are in update request body,
do an additional check to see if the values are actually
different. Only raise exception if values are different.

This backport partially picks change:
I2595335d6fbc51562b070f14eaeaadf49cf7c418. Specifically
the refactoring replacing the neutron.extensions.providernet
_raise_if_updates_provider_attributes method with the
neutron.plugins.ml2.plugin _update_provider_network_attributes
method.

Conflicts:
        neutron/extensions/providernet.py
	neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py
	neutron/tests/unit/plugins/ml2/test_plugin.py

Closes-Bug: #1822100
Co-Authored-By: Rodolfo Alonso Hernandez <ralonsoh@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I4ac11299375d1d3a7d2013f1fdc1742920d884a9
(cherry picked from commit 20743350b9b40fd7a2cff074bb2c877ea36c5914)

commit_message:
Add support for cinder NFS snapshots

Add CinderNfsSnapshotSupport parameter that controls whether cinder's
NFS driver supports snapshots. The default value is True.

Closes-bug: #1823101
Depends-On: I4df8e3941eb074339e399e5a5c44fa411ff21560
Change-Id: I9a42f805fd28fd04bee771cac63bd0080b39c7c0
(cherry picked from commit I9a42f805fd28fd04bee771cac63bd0080b39c7c0)

commit_message:
Create VNF with parameter file using scaling policy

If user provides parameter file while creating VNF using scaling
policy, earlier it was failing with error 'The Parameter was not
provided" This patch allows creation of VNF using scaling policy
with parameter file.

APIImpact
Return 200 instead of 400 error when VNF is created using scaling
policy with parameter file

Change-Id: If102519127a3ef63449ab59f849e8cfaaa3ae62b
Closes-Bug: #1799683

[{'created': '2019-03-04 20:04:07.000000000', 'message': 'Not set fip to ERROR if it exists on device

The centralized floating IP can exist on the router device
due to some reasons like: uncleaned fip addr, and especially
multiple IP addr adding action: HA router _add_vip() and
Edge router add_ip_address().
This patch catches the IpAddressAlreadyExists error if fip
was already set on the device, and still process next step.

Change-Id: I324f6b96baa0520a0f7ef62a83d81864d7b27999
Closes-Bug: #1811213
'}, {'created': '2019-04-09 22:39:53.000000000', 'message': 'Not set fip to ERROR if it exists on device

The centralized floating IP can exist on the router device
due to some reasons like: uncleaned fip addr, and especially
multiple IP addr adding action: HA router _add_vip() and
Edge router add_ip_address().
This patch catches the IpAddressAlreadyExists error if fip
was already set on the device, and still process next step.

Change-Id: I324f6b96baa0520a0f7ef62a83d81864d7b27999
Closes-Bug: #1811213
(cherry picked from commit 4d45699f155a6aa5732c27b572d3288963638ee3)
'}]
commit_message:
Not set fip to ERROR if it exists on device

The centralized floating IP can exist on the router device
due to some reasons like: uncleaned fip addr, and especially
multiple IP addr adding action: HA router _add_vip() and
Edge router add_ip_address().
This patch catches the IpAddressAlreadyExists error if fip
was already set on the device, and still process next step.

Change-Id: I324f6b96baa0520a0f7ef62a83d81864d7b27999
Closes-Bug: #1811213
(cherry picked from commit 4d45699f155a6aa5732c27b572d3288963638ee3)

commit_message:
Fix lower-constraints tox env to use proper constraints

- Bumps some of the lower constraints
- Fixes common/endpoint_utils.py to fallback to use auth_uri.

Change-Id: Ief0868d5feef3ee6b0689c6be27649ff009fbbcc

messages:
[{'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-02-05 16:35:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-02-05 16:41:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This needs removal on all cinder branches...

or want to keep it on old ones?'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-02-05 16:42:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I will propose the removal from stable branches as well.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-04-10 18:12:46.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Driver is still valid for older releases, so I will readdress this later if we do decide to stop testing against it.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-05 16:35:25.000000000', 'message': 'Remove legacy-tempest-dsvm-full-drbd-devstack job

The DRBD driver has been replaced by the new LINSTOR driver. This
removes the job for the old driver since it no longer supported.

Depends-on: https://review.openstack.org/634972
Depends-on: https://review.openstack.org/634969

Change-Id: Icacdb4d89b21f22fcf8c32816aeebd5cbdd0433d
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Remove legacy-tempest-dsvm-full-drbd-devstack job

The DRBD driver has been replaced by the new LINSTOR driver. This
removes the job for the old driver since it no longer supported.

Depends-on: https://review.openstack.org/634972
Depends-on: https://review.openstack.org/634969

Change-Id: Icacdb4d89b21f22fcf8c32816aeebd5cbdd0433d
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Update driver_opts directive logging

The sphinx directive "app" logging is deprecated in favor of using
logging. This switches our driver_opts extension to not use app.info.

Change-Id: I3b4f2c610040e331bbff40c04050e80f11f8538d
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-26 15:17:09.000000000', 'message': 'Fix NFS "already mounted" detection

Previous fix

2f32c98a RemoteFS: don't fail in do_mount if already mounted

was made with the assumption that "already mounted" appearing
in stderr from an NFS mount means that the NFS share was already
mounted.

However, the NFS client can fail with "busy or already mounted"
in cases where it fails to mount the share as well.

This results in the Cinder NFS backup driver believing that the
NFS mount has succeeded when it didn't, and as a result, data
can be written to the local disk instead of the NFS target.

Fail if the share isn't actually mounted rather than succeeding.

Related-Bug: #1780813
Closes-Bug: #1797233
Change-Id: Iebd1afb3340fcaeb1969784966c4f9be35a28417
(cherry picked from commit 360a20c7c7b4c385255200a574edc0ca1ac8d87c)
(cherry picked from commit 4c94477cb525b25f178d52ff1b01bfe1fc3d3dd3)
(cherry picked from commit 30d7bc124e564d4a2c288f3666d8d14dc96fb9f5)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix NFS "already mounted" detection

Previous fix

2f32c98a RemoteFS: don't fail in do_mount if already mounted

was made with the assumption that "already mounted" appearing
in stderr from an NFS mount means that the NFS share was already
mounted.

However, the NFS client can fail with "busy or already mounted"
in cases where it fails to mount the share as well.

This results in the Cinder NFS backup driver believing that the
NFS mount has succeeded when it didn't, and as a result, data
can be written to the local disk instead of the NFS target.

Fail if the share isn't actually mounted rather than succeeding.

Related-Bug: #1780813
Closes-Bug: #1797233
Change-Id: Iebd1afb3340fcaeb1969784966c4f9be35a28417
(cherry picked from commit 360a20c7c7b4c385255200a574edc0ca1ac8d87c)
(cherry picked from commit 4c94477cb525b25f178d52ff1b01bfe1fc3d3dd3)
(cherry picked from commit 30d7bc124e564d4a2c288f3666d8d14dc96fb9f5)

commit_message:
Set ulimit 16384 for Neutron SR-IOV container

Same a in [1], rootwrap takes too much time if ulimit is the
default value. In the related bug, the execution time drops
from 800ms to 30ms if ulimit is set to 16384.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/559268/

Change-Id: I18de5b733066853a8c057596e85299048cee8604
Closes-Bug: #1823385
